speaker: Neil
text: Hello, I’m Neil. And welcome to 6 Minute English, where we vigorously discuss a new topic and six related items of vocabulary.

speaker: Vigorous
text: And hello, I’m Rob. Today we’re discussing vigorous exercise – and whether adults take enough of it! Vigorous means using a lot of energy to do something.

speaker: Neil
text: So how many steps do you do in a day, Rob?

speaker: Rob
text: How many steps? How should I know, Neil? – It would be pretty hard to count them all.

speaker: Neil
text: Oh, come on! You can track steps on your phone! I do ten thousand a day – which is the magic number for keeping fit and healthy, apparently.

speaker: Rob
text: Not if you saunter, Neil, surely? Sauntering from the sofa to the fridge and back – Or from the house to the car.

speaker: Saunter
text: Well I never saunter, Rob. Saunter means to walk slowly. And you’d have to make a lot of trips to the fridge to clock up ten thousand steps. To get some vigorous exercise, you need to get out and about – round the park at a brisk pace…

speaker: Brisk
text: Brisk means quick and energetic – the opposite of sauntering. OK, well, perhaps you can you tell me, Neil, how many people aged between 40 and 60 do less than ten minutes brisk walking every month? Is it…

speaker: Brisk
text: b) 14% or

speaker: Neil
text: I’m going to say… 4% because ten minutes is such a short amount of time!

speaker: Rob
text: Indeed. Now, I’ve got another question for you, Neil. Why is exercise so important? Because it sounds pretty boring – counting steps, going to the gym, running on a machine.

speaker: Neil
text: Well, when you exercise, you stimulate the body’s natural repair system. Your body will actually stay younger if you exercise!

speaker: Rob
text: That sounds good.

speaker: Neil
text: Exercise also lowers your risk of developing illnesses such as heart disease, cancer, and diabetes.

speaker: Rob
text: Hmm. I’m getting a bit worried now, Neil. But I don’t have enough time to do a thousand steps every day… I’m far too busy!

speaker: Neil
text: Well, Rob. Now might be a good time to listen to Julia Bradbury. She’s a TV presenter and outdoor walking enthusiast who will explain how she builds walking into her busy life.

speaker: INSERT
text: Julia Bradbury, TV presenter and outdoor walking enthusiast

speaker: INSERT
text: I will walk to meetings instead of catching a bus, or getting a taxi or a car – into meetings. And I will also, if I can’t build that into my working day, if it’s a day when I haven’t got meetings and I’m maybe at home with the kids, I will take the time – I will take my kids out with the buggy and I will definitely do 30-40 minutes at least everyday. Going to the park, going to the shops, picking up my things up en route, and really sort of building it into my life. Taking the stairs and not taking lifts, all of these kinds of little decisions can incrementally build up to create more walking time in your day.

speaker: build something in
text: So if you build something in to your day – or your life – you include it from the beginning.

speaker: Neil
text: And Julia Bradbury has built walking into her day. Even though she’s very busy too, Rob! You should learn from her!

speaker: Rob
text: So she walks instead of driving or taking the bus. And takes the stairs instead of the lift. I could do those things.

speaker: Neil
text: You could indeed – before you know it, you’d be doing ten thousand steps – because the amount of walking you do in a day builds incrementally.

speaker: Rob
text: Incrementally means gradually increasing in size. OK, well, before I think that over, perhaps I could tell you the answer to today’s quiz question?

speaker: Neil
text: OK. You asked me: How many people aged between 40 and 60 do less than ten minutes brisk walking every month? The options were:

speaker: Neil
text: b) 14% or

speaker: Rob
text: And you said 4%. But I’m afraid it’s actually 40%. And that’s according to the Government body Public Health England here in the UK.

speaker: sedentary
text: Oh dear, that’s a lot more people than I expected. But it isn’t that surprising – people in all age groups are leading more sedentary lifestyles these days. Our job is very sedentary – which means it involves a lot of sitting and not much exercise!

speaker: Rob
text: Well, I might just run on the spot while we go over the new vocabulary we’ve learned today!

speaker: Neil
text: Good plan. First up we heard ‘vigorous’ – which means using a lot of energy to do something.

speaker: Rob
text: OK. “I am running vigorously on the spot!”

speaker: Neil
text: Great example! And good to see you taking some vigorous exercise! Number two – ‘saunter’ – means to walk slowly in a relaxed way. “When I saw Rob, I sauntered over to say hello.”

speaker: Rob
text: Hi Neil. Number three – ‘brisk’ means quick and energetic.

speaker: Neil
text: “It’s important to take some brisk exercise every day.”

speaker: Rob
text: Yes! And I’m beginning to realise that might be true.

speaker: Neil
text: Yep! I think you've done enough jogging for today, Rob. You’ve probably done about a hundred steps.

speaker: Rob
text: Is that all? OK, number four – if you ‘build something in to something’ – you include it from the beginning.

speaker: Neil
text: “It’s important to build regular exercise into your daily routine.”

speaker: Rob
text: Very good advice. Number five is ‘incrementally’ which means gradually increasing in size.

speaker: Neil
text: Incremental is the adjective. “The company has been making incremental changes to its pay structure.”

speaker: Rob
text: Does that mean we’re getting a pay rise?

speaker: Neil
text: I doubt it! And finally, number six – ‘sedentary’ means sitting a lot and not taking much exercise. For example, “It’s bad for your health to lead such a sedentary lifestyle.”

speaker: Rob
text: Duly noted, Neil! Well, it’s time to go now. But if today’s show has inspired you to step out and take more exercise, please let us know by visiting our Twitter, Facebook and YouTube pages and telling us about it!

speaker: Neil
text: Goodbye!

speaker: Rob
text: Bye bye!
